thread.title: Sydney battered by storms causing flash flooding
thread.title_full: Sydney battered by storms causing flash flooding | Daily Mail Online

author: Nic White For Daily Mail Australia
title: Sydney battered by storms causing flash flooding
text:
Torrential rain and flash flooding is turning Sydney streets into rivers, bursting pipes and throwing traffic into chaos.
The weather bureau issued a severe thunderstorm warning for much of the city with the rain to continue for hours as the storm is slow-moving.
In just one hour 48 millimetres of rain fell in Marrickville, 45 millimetres in Canterbury, and 35 millimetres in the Sydney CBD.
Scroll down for video
Torrential rain and flash flooding is turning Sydney streets into rivers, bursting pipes (pictured) and throwing traffic into chaos
The SES was warning people to stay out of affected areas and not drive through floodwaters, as many cars are already stuck
The weather bureau issued a severe thunderstorm warning for much of the city with the rain to continue for hours as the storm is slow-moving
This was as much as the 48 millimetres that fell in the whole of last month, with 32 millimeteres falling between 10.30 and 11am.
The 50 millimetres that have fallen since 9am make it the wettest day since August 4 last year.
But the onslaught was not over with the bureau warning a second storm cell would hit Western Sydney at 12.25pm before moving east towards the city.
Flooding is reported in Penrith, Parramatta, Wollongong, Campbelltown and Port Kembla, Marrickville, Zetland, Woollahra and the Sydney CBD.
Waether bureau's radar showed heavy rainfall across Sydney
Flooding is reported in Penrith, Parramatta, Wollongong, Campbelltown and Port Kembla, Marrickville, Zetland, Woollahra and the Sydney CBD
The CBD was blanketed by a heavy torrent of rain on Tuesday morning
A Maserati sports car suck in a Redfern street transformed into a river
The State Emergency Service is rescuing people trapped by floodwaters in Marrickville and Zetland.
It was inundated with reports of roofs falling in, homes flooded and cars trapped.
An apartment building on Ewart Street in Marrickville is in danger of collapsed after a 'waterhole' next to in filled up with water.
SES warned people to stay out of affected areas and not drive through floodwaters, as many cars are already stuck.
One of the many roads closed by knee-deep flooding around Sydney
It is the wettest day since August 4 last year with 50 millimetres falling alreay
A pipe bursts next to a street next to an inner-west street
A cyclist struggles to pedal through flooded Elizabeth Street near St James station
A woman doused by a passing bus ploughing through flooded street
A woman struggles with her umbrella which has been battered by high winds
Sydney Airport said there were almost 2,500 lightning strikes within 10 nautical miles of the airport so far.
Light rail services were cancelled between Dulwich Hill and Central were quickly due to flooding along the line and trees fell across the tracks near Rooty Hill and Wolli Creek.
Traffic is on a standstill on major bridges not only from delays but from flooding on the bridge themselves, with the Anzac bridge reportedly worst affected.
In just one hour 48 millimetres of rain fell in Marrickville, 45 millimetres in Canterbury, and 35 millimetres in the Sydney CBD
Rain falling quickly as a woman crosses the road in inner Sydney
Teenagers drenched as they walk with only one umbrella between four of them
A woman runs through the rain to avoid getting too wet
Pedestrians huddle under collapsing umbrellas in the brutal storm
Scooters submerged up to their wheels in flooded a CBD street
Sydney Airport said it was operating normally but there could be delays as the day went on, and was later reportedly shut.
Several flights were forced to circle the airport until it was safe to land and others were diverted to Melbourne and Canberra.
Some passengers on a flight from Adelaide could miss their cruise setting sail for New Caledonia, as could others who won tickets to Ed Sheeran's concert at the Sydney Opera House in the evening.
Virgin said 'a number' of its flights were delayed by the weather.
